title: 112_s3077
content: The Act is titled the "Pro Football Hall of Fame Commemorative Coin Act" and includes findings. The Pro Football Hall of Fame was established to honor individuals who have made significant contributions to professional football, preserve its history, educate the public about the sport's development, and promote its positive values. It opened on September 7, 1963, inducting a charter class of 17 players, coaches, and contributors. Membership in the Hall of Fame is represented by a bronze bust, a gold jacket, and a ring, with a total of 273 members elected as of 2012. The Pro Football Hall of Fame, established in 1963, has 273 members. It has grown to a 118,000-square-foot facility with expansions and renovations over the years. The museum houses the world's largest collection on professional football, including over 20,000 artifacts and 20 million pages of documents. It reaches a worldwide audience of nearly 15 million people annually. The Pro Football Hall of Fame has over 20,000 artifacts and 20 million pages of documents, including 3 million photographic images. It reaches a global audience of nearly 15 million people annually through various channels. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half-dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. These coins will be legal tender according to the United States Code. The coins minted under this Act are legal tender and considered numismatic items under the United States Code. The coins minted under this Act shall have a design emblematic of professional football, with inscriptions including the coin's value, year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5 of the Act specifies that coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single mint facility for a 1-year period starting January 1, 2016. SEC. 6 addresses the sale of these coins. SEC. 6 of the Act outlines the sale of coins by the Secretary, including pricing factors and bulk sales. Prepaid orders are accepted at a discount. All sales of coins issued under this Act include surcharges of $35 per $5 coin, $10 per $1 coin, and $5 per half-dollar coin. Surcharges are promptly paid to the Pro Football Hall of Fame for construction and renovation. The Hall of Fame is subject to audit requirements for the amounts received. No surcharge can be included if it exceeds the annual commemorative coin program issuance limitation. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance to limit the number of commemorative coin programs issued in a calendar year to avoid exceeding the annual issuance limitation under section 5112(m)(1) of title 31, United States Code.
